title: ClassWork7
text:
library(rnaturalearth)
library(rnaturalearthdata)


Attaching package: 'rnaturalearthdata'


The following object is masked from 'package:rnaturalearth':

    countries110

# Run this in your console first
# devtools::install_github("ropensci/rnaturalearthhires")
library(rnaturalearthhires)

# Plotting Maps
library(tidyverse) # Maps using ggplot() + geom_sf()

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.2
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0

✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(ggformula) # Maps using gf_sf()

Loading required package: scales

Attaching package: 'scales'

The following object is masked from 'package:purrr':

    discard

The following object is masked from 'package:readr':

    col_factor

Loading required package: ggridges

New to ggformula?  Try the tutorials: 
    learnr::run_tutorial("introduction", package = "ggformula")
    learnr::run_tutorial("refining", package = "ggformula")

library(tmap) # Thematic Maps, static and interactive
library(tmaptools)
library(tmap.mapgl)
library(osmdata) # Fetch map data from osmdata.org

Data (c) OpenStreetMap contributors, ODbL 1.0. https://www.openstreetmap.org/copyright

library(sfheaders) # Handcrafted Map data
## Interactive Maps
library(leaflet) # interactive Maps
library(leaflet)
library(leaflet.providers)
library(leaflet.extras)
library(leaflet.extras) # Globe maps in R. Part of the htmlwidgets family of packages

# For Spatial Data Frame Processing
library(sf)

Linking to GEOS 3.13.0, GDAL 3.8.5, PROJ 9.5.1; sf_use_s2() is TRUE


77.5680726566,13.0060480699,77.5731959698,13.0099049656

bbox_1 <- matrix(c(77.5680726566,13.0060480699,77.5731959698,13.0099049656), byrow = FALSE, nrow = 2,
    ncol = 2, dimnames = list(c("x", "y"), c("min", "max")))
bbox_1

       min     max
x 77.56807 77.5732
y 13.00605 13.0099



# Using getbb command from the osmdata package
bbox_2 <- osmdata::getbb("Malleswaram, Bangalore, India")
bbox_2

       min      max
x 77.55033 77.59033
y 12.98274 13.02274



#|eeval: false

locations <- 
  osmdata::opq(bbox = bbox_2) %>% 
  osmdata::add_osm_feature(key = "amenity", 
                           value = c("restaurant", "atm", "college")) %>% 
  osmdata_sf() %>%  # Convert to Simple Features format
  purrr::pluck("osm_points") # Pull out the data frame of interest

# Get all buildings within my bbox
dat_buildings <-
  osmdata::opq(bbox = bbox_2) %>% 
  osmdata::add_osm_feature(key = "building") %>% 
  osmdata_sf() %>% 
  purrr::pluck("osm_polygons") 

# Get all residential roads within my bbox
dat_roads <- 
  osmdata::opq(bbox = bbox_2) %>% 
  osmdata::add_osm_feature(key = "highway") %>% 
  osmdata_sf() %>% 
  purrr::pluck("osm_lines") 

# Get all parks / natural /greenery areas and spots within my bbox
dat_natural <-   
  osmdata::opq(bbox = bbox_2) %>% 
  osmdata::add_osm_feature(key = "natural",
                           value = c("tree", "water", "wood")) %>% 
  osmdata_sf()
dat_natural

Object of class 'osmdata' with:
                 $bbox : 12.9827353,77.5503253,13.0227353,77.5903253
        $overpass_call : The call submitted to the overpass API
                 $meta : metadata including timestamp and version numbers
           $osm_points : 'sf' Simple Features Collection with 2376 points
            $osm_lines : 'sf' Simple Features Collection with 3 linestrings
         $osm_polygons : 'sf' Simple Features Collection with 96 polygons
       $osm_multilines : NULL
    $osm_multipolygons : 'sf' Simple Features Collection with 1 multipolygons

dat_trees <- 
  dat_natural %>% 
  purrr::pluck("osm_points") 


roads <- st_read("osm_data/dat_roads.gpkg")

Reading layer `dat_roads' from data source 
  `/Users/ashmitabiswas/Documents/R_work/Class work 2/ClassWork2/osm_data/dat_roads.gpkg' 
  using driver `GPKG'
Simple feature collection with 5660 features and 142 fields
Geometry type: LINESTRING
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 77.5457 ymin: 12.97885 xmax: 77.59599 ymax: 13.03094
Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84

trees <- st_read("osm_data/dat_trees.gpkg")

Reading layer `dat_trees' from data source 
  `/Users/ashmitabiswas/Documents/R_work/Class work 2/ClassWork2/osm_data/dat_trees.gpkg' 
  using driver `GPKG'
Simple feature collection with 2376 features and 19 fields
Geometry type: POINT
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 77.55037 ymin: 12.98239 xmax: 77.59089 ymax: 13.02776
Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84

buildings <- st_read("osm_data/dat_buildins.gpkg")

Reading layer `dat_buildins' from data source 
  `/Users/ashmitabiswas/Documents/R_work/Class work 2/ClassWork2/osm_data/dat_buildins.gpkg' 
  using driver `GPKG'
Simple feature collection with 26530 features and 133 fields
Geometry type: POLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 77.54975 ymin: 12.982 xmax: 77.59085 ymax: 13.02331
Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84

greenery <- st_read("osm_data/dat_greenery.gpkg")

Reading layer `dat_greenery' from data source 
  `/Users/ashmitabiswas/Documents/R_work/Class work 2/ClassWork2/osm_data/dat_greenery.gpkg' 
  using driver `GPKG'
Simple feature collection with 96 features and 10 fields
Geometry type: POLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 77.55095 ymin: 12.98239 xmax: 77.59089 ymax: 13.02776
Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84



gf_sf(data = buildings, geometry = ~ geom, color = "#d4b17a") %>% 
  gf_sf(data = greenery, geometry = ~ geom, color = "lightgreen") %>% 
  gf_sf(data = roads, geometry = ~ geom, color = "lightblue", linewidth = 0.2) %>% 
  gf_sf(data = trees, geometry = ~ geom, color = "darkgreen")









gf_sf(data = roads, geometry = ~ geom)

title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

title: Weekly Expenditure
text:
How much do Srishti students spend in a week?


This data set is derived from the peasants of Srishti Manipal Institute to analyse the spending behaviour in a week.




: Name: Name of the student

Gender: Gender of the students categorized as ‘Male’ & ‘Female’


Total_Expenditure_Last_Week: Total amount of money spent in the last week by the student






Will Friends have significantly higher ratings than Big Bang Theory due to broader cultural popularity and peer influence?
Is there a difference in spending behaviour amongst the different gender?

title: Dads are weird
text:
About the Data
This data set is derived from the peasants of Manipal University to analyse the ratings of classic tv series - Friends, Modern Family, and Big Bang Theory

title: Dads are weird
text:
Data Dictionary

: gender: Gender of the student where, categorized by ‘Male’ and ‘Female’

college: Institute within Manipal University, the peasant belongs to.


is_dad_weird: Is the dad perceived as weird or not, categorized by ‘Yes’ and ‘No’


name: Name of the student (aka. peasant)

title: Dads are weird
text:
Hypothesis

Do SMI students find their dads to be weirder as compared to MIT
Is there a bias in gender when it comes do dad weirdness perception of dads.


Setup

title: Post With Code
text:
This is a post with executable code.

1 + 1

[1] 2

title: Tattoos are attractive?
text:
Tattoos or taboos? Analyzing the perception about tattoos.



This data set is derived from the peasants of Srishti Manipal Institute to analyse the proportions of non-tattooed people who find tattoos attractive✨.




Qualitative Variables

Name: Name of the student


Gender: Gender of the student where; M = Male, F = Female


Tattoos_Attractive: Students’ perception about tattoos being attractive or not






Being in an art and design college, will the proportion of people finding tattoos attractive be more or be the same i.e. 1:1?
Does gender play a role in the way tattoos are perceived as?





── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──

tattoo_data_mod1 <- tattoo_data %>% 
mutate(gender = as.factor(gender),
tattoo_attractive = as.factor(tattoo_attractive))








glimpse(tattoo_data_mod1)

Rows: 40
Columns: 3
$ name              <chr> "Aadya", "Abhinav", "Aditya", "Akash", "Amit", "Amog…
$ gender            <fct> F, M, M, M, M, M, M, M, M, F, M, F, M, F, M, F, F, M…
$ tattoo_attractive <fct> Yes, Yes, No, Yes, No, Yes, Yes, Yes, Yes, No, Yes, …


There are a total of 40 entries




tattoo_data_mod1 %>% 
  dplyr::count(gender) %>%
  tt()



    

    
    
      
        
        
              
                gender
                n
              
        
        
        
                
                  F
                  20
                
                
                  M
                  20
                
        
      
    






There is an equal number of male and female representation






tattoo_data_mod1 %>% 
  dplyr::count(tattoo_attractive) %>% 
  tt()



    

    
    
      
        
        
              
                tattoo_attractive
                n
              
        
        
        
                
                  No
                  10
                
                
                  Yes
                  30
                
        
      
    




tattoo_data_mod1 %>% 
gf_bar(~tattoo_attractive, fill = "navy") %>% 
gf_labs(title = "Do students find tattoos attractive?",
       x = "Are tattoos attractive?",
       y = "Number of students")











We can see that exactly 75% of the students find tattoos attractive
This maybe due to the influence of the environment where tattoos are looked as a normal mark to have and/or younger generation embracing tattoos.






tattoo_data_mod1 %>% 
gf_bar(~tattoo_attractive, fill = ~gender, position = "dodge") %>% 
gf_labs(title = "Tattoo Attractiveness by Gender",
       x = "Are tattoos attractive?",
       y = "Number of students")









tattoo_data_mod1 %>% 
gf_bar(~tattoo_attractive, fill = ~gender, position = "fill") %>% 
gf_labs(title = "Tattoo Attractiveness by Gender",
       x = "Are tattoos attractive?",
       y = "Number of students")









tattoo_data_mod1 %>% 
    count(across(c("gender", "tattoo_attractive"))) %>%
  tt()



    

    
    
      
        
        
              
                gender
                tattoo_attractive
                n
              
        
        
        
                
                  F
                  No
                  5
                
                
                  F
                  Yes
                  15
                
                
                  M
                  No
                  5
                
                
                  M
                  Yes
                  15
                
        
      
    






There is an equal distribution amongst the 2 genders, which leads to the belief that there might be no gender bias in the perception of tattoos being attractive to the 2 genders.


vcd::structable(gender ~ tattoo_attractive, data = tattoo_data_mod1) %>%
  as.matrix() %>%
  addmargins() %>%
  as_tibble(rownames = "gender")

# A tibble: 3 × 4
  gender     F     M   Sum
  <chr>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
1 No         5     5    10
2 Yes       15    15    30
3 Sum       20    20    40

vcd::structable(gender ~ tattoo_attractive, data = tattoo_data_mod1) %>%
  vcd::mosaic(shade = TRUE, legend = TRUE,
              main = "Tattoo Attractiveness by Gender")

Warning in legend(residuals, gpfun, residuals_type): All residuals are zero.














The p value = 1 between Gender and Tattoo attractiveness.
This means there is no gender bias and the variables are independent / have no correlation to on another.

title: Tattoos are attractive?
text: This data set is derived from the peasants of Srishti Manipal Institute to analyse the proportions of non-tattooed people who find tattoos attractive✨.

title: Tattoos are attractive?
text:
Qualitative Variables

Name: Name of the student


Gender: Gender of the student where; M = Male, F = Female


Tattoos_Attractive: Students’ perception about tattoos being attractive or not

title: Tattoos are attractive?
text:
Being in an art and design college, will the proportion of people finding tattoos attractive be more or be the same i.e. 1:1?
Does gender play a role in the way tattoos are perceived as?

title: Believe in Gods
text:
Beleive in God
[Add somthing]
About the Data
This data set is derived from peasants from Srishti Manipal Institute to analyse the proportions of non-tattooed people who find tattoos attractive✨.
Data Dictionary
Qualitative Variables
Name: Name of the student
Gender: Gender of the student where; M = Male, F = Female
Tattoos_Attractive: Students’ perception about tattoos being attractive or not
